urn:contentItem:5WK9-X371-JCF2-802C-00000-00Dangers of being smart;Home security cameras, digital locks and other smart devices can be used by hackers to invade users' privacy, so be careful when you go high tech at home2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:39ZLexisNexisLIFEDangers of being smartHome security cameras, digital locks and other smart devices can be used by hackers to invade users' privacy, so be careful when you go high tech at homeVincent Chang

It is a recurring nightmare for technology professionals.

A database server exposed online without a password, open to anyone, including hackers trawling the Internet for vulnerabilities.

Last month, one such unprotected server is owned by Orvibo, a Chinese firm that makes smart home gadgets such as security cameras and smart door locks that are sold in Singapore.

Over two billion records with important data, such as precise locations and the password reset codes, belonging to around one million users of Orvibo's smart home devices were stored in the server, which was exposed for two weeks despite warnings from researchers.

Cyber-security experts say the leaked Orvibo data could have been used to hijack user accounts.

For instance, your own security camera could be used by hackers to spy on you.

In recent years, data breaches have affected a wide range of organisations, from hotel group Marriott International to tech giants Google and Facebook. Last year, hackers stole the records of 1.5 million SingHealth patients in Singapore's worst cyber attack.

The Orvibo incident, however, reflects a newer concern.

Given that it involves a rapidly growing segment consisting of smart, Internet-connected home gadgets, are security and privacy incidents set to worsen'

"By using voice-activated devices and security cameras in our homes and offices, it could be argued that we're building the infrastructure for those with malicious intent to spy on our conversations and actions," said Mr Jason Hatch, a senior director at cloud services provider Akamai Asia-Pacific.

Tech giants Amazon and Google made headlines recently for retaining audio conversations between users and their virtual assistant software - found in smart speakers and smartphones - that were to be reviewed by employees to improve speech recognition.

In Google's case, a Belgian news site reported last Wednesday it had obtained samples of these conversations from a contract worker - a breach of privacy.

While Orvibo is not a household name in Singapore like Amazon and Google, its devices have been adopted by smart home enthusiasts here. They were bundled by Sembcorp Power in a recent promotion for its electricity plans.

Orvibo also makes the Kyla range of smart home devices sold by local conglomerate Aztech. The latter told The Straits Times its data is secured in a different server from the one affected by the breach.

Smart home enthusiast S.H. Lim, 39, an IT consultant, first learnt about the breach from a friend. But he is not too worried as the "more important things such as security camera and digital door lock" are controlled by a separate system.

IT consultant Gayatri Satyavarpu, who bought an Orvibo product for a relative, said she will give Orvibo another chance if it improves its cyber security.

"We have had security breaches in Google and other big tech firms, but we still use them as they sorted the problems out and regained our confidence," she said.

Smart connected devices are increasingly finding their way into homes.

Research firm IDC said the global market for smart home devices is expected to grow by 26.9 per cent this year to 832.7 million shipments, with Amazon and Google dominating the market due to their popular smart speakers.

In Singapore, sales of these gadgets grew by 24 per cent last year compared with the year before, said research firm GfK Asia.

Mr Edwin Tan, who runs IoT (Internet of Things) consultancy Automate Asia, observed that sales have gone up by around 200 per cent last year compared with 2017.

He has also received a threefold increase in queries about smart homes since the launch of the Google Home smart speaker in Singapore last April.

The growth of these smart home devices "increases the number of targets for attack and the potential impact of a breach - if the systems are not secured", said Akamai's Mr Hatch.

Cyber-security firm Kaspersky Lab's general manager for South-east Asia, Mr Yeo Siang Tiong, expects cyber attacks against IoT devices to "intensify in terms of volume as well as sophistication".

Already, the variants of malware used against IoT devices last year had more than tripled compared with 2017, he said.

Cyber-security experts warned that the consequences of data theft related to smart home devices could be more serious than the usual data breach.

Mr Ofer Maor, director at tech firm Synopsys, said: "With smart devices integrating into locks and windows, attackers can use cyber attacks to achieve a physical compromise - breaking into your house without having to pick a lock or break a window."

He added that once hackers get a foothold in the home network, they can target other devices in the home network that contain confidential data such as computers and smartphones.

Orvibo is not the only smart home vendor to suffer privacy or security lapses.

In recent years, manufacturers such as Asus and D-Link have been sued by the United States Federal Trade Commission over the poor security in their smart devices such as routers and security cameras.

Cyber-security experts offered several reasons for security lapses in the smart home industry.

Synopsys' Mr Maor said vendors in the smart home business are racing to launch new innovative products in the most cost-effective manner. As a result, security, especially for smaller firms, is often a secondary concern.

Consumers, too, are not helping matters by choosing smart home products based on price rather than factors such as the trustworthiness of the vendors, said Mr Tan of Automate Asia.

Mr Steve Tan, a partner at Rajah & Tann Singapore and adjunct professor at the National University of Singapore's law faculty, said the poor state of IoT security is "exacerbated by the fact that there is presently no mandatory global security standards" for these devices.

But the situation looks set to improve.

Last year, California introduced a cyber-security law that will go into effect next year and requires IoT device makers to equip their devices with "reasonable" security features, such as having users set their own unique passwords the first time they use the devices.

US lawmakers are also considering legislation to encourage IoT manufacturers to build more secure devices by mandating that devices sold to the federal government meet specific security requirements.

While describing such regulations as long overdue, Mr Tan said it is insufficient for regulatory security standards to be specific to a country.

"What is needed is a global standard, internationally recognised and implemented for IoT devices, requiring all manufacturers of such devices to conform to specific security standards," he said.

A spokesman for the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore told The Straits Times the Government "currently has no plans to put in place legislation for IoT products", though he said the IT Standards Committee has recently published guidelines to safeguard IoT systems.

Adopting these guidelines can help vendors "achieve a baseline cyber hygiene level for their products, while avoiding piecemeal and costly retrofitting should their products be compromised by security at a later stage", he said.

Mr Oded Vanunu, head of products vulnerability research at cyber-security firm Check Point Software Technologies, said legislation could be an effective approach.

"It's like when you buy a food product, you can see on the package what ingredients there are and the nutritional value. There is no reason why it is not the same with smart home devices."


ST ILLUSTRATION: LIM YONG

Minimise the risks of your smart home being compromised with these tips.

That shiny new smart home gadget on the Kickstarter crowdfunding website may look tempting, but it is safer to buy from established brands with the resources to spend on security.

Smart home security starts with your Wi-Fi router. Ensure that its default password has been changed to a strong password.

Vendors usually require users to create an account to manage smart home devices. Turn on two-factor authentication for the account if it is available.

Do not use the same password across multiple user accounts - consider using a password manager software to help you generate strong and unique passwords, then manage them with a single master password.

Apply the latest software patches to fix potential security vulnerabilities. Check that the auto-update feature - available in newer smart home devices - is enabled.

Consider using an IoT scanner to assess the security of your smart home devices. This could be a software app, such as the Kaspersky Smart Home & IoT scanner (available for Android) or a hardware product such as Trend Micro's Home Network Security appliance.

Similar security features are also available in certain models of routers from Asus, D-Link and TP-Link.

Do you really need to be able to control your home lighting while you are away from home'

Disable remote access for smart devices that do not require such functionality, such as smart plugs. Doing so will prevent them being targeted by hackers.

Before you dispose of or sell any of your smart home devices, reset them to their factory default settings. This is usually done by pressing a tiny reset button with a pin. This ensures that personal information stored in the device is deleted.

Because most smart home devices are managed using smartphone apps, it is important the phone itself is secure.

Lock the phone with a strong password or use biometric authentication like a fingerprint.

You can also install mobile security apps in your phone to reduce the risk of malware.

urn:contentItem:5TRK-YGK1-F066-M1CB-00000-00Daniel Kretinsky, le Tchèque qui bouscule la presse française2018-11-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:39ZLexisNexisARTICLEUn francophile avéréPg. 19Daniel Kretinsky, le Tchèque qui bouscule la presse françaiseVERONIQUE LE BILLON

PORTRAIT - Le Tchèque Daniel Kretinsky a fait une entrée fracassante dans la presse française, avec le rachat de titres Lagardère et de « Marianne » puis son entrée au capital du « Monde » le mois dernier. Adepte des coups de poker, il s'est déjà imposé parmi les leaders européens de l'énergie, en s'entourant parfois de personnages plus sulfureux.


« C'était très très sympa. »Il sort, tout sourire, de sa première rencontre avec la rédaction deMarianneen France, dont il est propriétaire depuis cet été. Daniel Kretinsky, « le Tchèque » dont parle tout le microcosme médiatique depuis son irruption dans le capital du quotidienLe Mondeest, lui aussi, très « sympa ». Sourire facile, yeux rieurs, un brin timide, « Dan », comme l'appellent les journalistes à Prague, sait se faire apprécier de ses interlocuteurs. L'homme, qui a fait fortune dans l'énergieen Europe et possède le premier groupe de presse de son pays, surprend autant qu'il fascine.

Un francophile avéré

Il reçoit dans les salons duGeorge Voù il a ses habitudes à Paris, jouant profil bas, avec ses airs de bon élève.« Oui, pas de problème, vous pouvez enregistrer l'interview, cela vous aidera à décoder mon français ! »plaisante-il alors qu'il s'exprime très bien dans la langue de Molière, avec un léger accent slave. Lui qui a fait une partie de ses études de droit à Dijon, se décrit comme francophile.« Le français, c'est ma première langue étrangère. J'aime votre pays et votre culture. Cela vient de ma famille : ma mère écoutait des chansons françaises et regardait les films français... J'ai fait beaucoup d'échanges avec la France au lycée, et j'y suis revenu voir mes amis, tout le temps », raconte l'homme d'affairesné d'une mère juge à la cour constitutionnelle et d'un père professeur d'informatique, à Brno, la cité de Milan Kundera, deuxième plus grande ville tchèque.

Cet amateur d'art moderne tchèque, plutôt sobre dans ses tenues vestimentaires, possède deux catamarans.« C'est ce qu'il faut pour réunir la famille et les amis », dit-il. Mais ils lui ont valu d'être cité dans les « Panama papers ». « Le propriétaire qui m'a vendu le bateau avait une société administrée par une société panaméenne. Je ne l'ai conservée que deux mois avant de changer cela », se justifie-t-il.

Elle, Télé 7 Jours, Publicet France Dimanche...

Il aime tellement la France qu'en quelques mois, il s'est offert plusieurs grandes marques de la presse tricolore. Le premier à lui avoir ouvert la porte, c'est Arnaud Lagardère qui, en plus de lui vendre ses radios d'Europe de l'Est, a ajouté dans la corbeille les magazinesElle, Télé 7 Jours, PublicetFrance Dimanche.« Les acquisitions tchèques en France sont très rares, note un avocat d'affaires vivant à Prague.Il y a bien quelques rachats de PME, mais c'est la première fois qu'un Tchèque s'offre des fleurons. »

En réalité, même s'il ne laisse rien paraître, Daniel Kretinsky est au centre d'un dossier brûlant. Nul n'ignore qu'il a tenté, cet été, de prendre le cocontrôle duMondeen rachetant au prix fort (110 millions d'euros) la part de Matthieu Pigasse, coactionnaire du journal avec Xavier Niel. Acculé par ses dettes et forcé de vendre, celui qui est par ailleurs responsable mondial des fusions-aquisitions chez Lazard a finalement reculé à la dernière minute pour ne céder que 49% de sa part.

Révélée par une fuite aux salariés, eux aussi actionnaires du quotidien du soir, la nouvelle passe mal, très mal, car ils n'ont pas été consultés.« Je suis sincèrement désolé de la manière dont cette information a été rendue publique », s'excuse Daniel Kretinsky, en baissant les yeux comme un enfant coupable.

Les journalistes duMondesont choqués. Ils ont répliqué en multipliant portraits et enquêtes sur cet actionnaire qui vient de l'Est. Les journaux ne sont pas des entreprises comme les autres : on n'y entre pas par effraction. Lorsque l'on convoite l'un des quotidiens les plus influents de France, on se présente d'abord, on explique les raisons de son investissement ensuite, on s'engage à respecter l'indépendance des journalistes enfin. Daniel Kretinsky a tout fait à l'envers...

Un caractère dominant

Mais qui est ce milliardaire de 43 ans, cinquième fortune de la République tchèque avec 2,5 milliards de dollars selonForbes, inconnu en France jusqu'alors, qui fait main basse sur la presse française depuis quelques mois ?« Mon métier principal, c'est l'énergie », rappelle-t-il. Il n'a fallu que dix ans à Daniel Kretinsky pour construire EPH. D'abord très minoritaire aux côtés de ses deux mentors, Patrik Tkac et Petr Kellner - première fortune tchèque -, il est envoyé au front pour réaliser les acquisitions qui propulsent le groupe sur le devant de la scène européenne. Aujourd'hui dans le Top 15 des énergéticiens du Vieux Continent, il réalise 90% de son business en dehors de Tchéquie. Les rachats d'entreprises, c'est sa spécialité, lui qui a débuté comme juriste au sein de la société d'investissement J&T, très connue et parfois controversée à Prague, où Patrik Tkac l'a fait entrer.

« J&T renferme une bonne partie de l'histoire du capitalisme tchèque, avec de nombreux clients riches. Mais il y a des points obscurs, notamment sur l'origine des fonds... Même s'il n'y a jamais eu de scandale », affirme un journaliste tchèque. C'est dans cette société que Kretinsky commence à faire ses « deals ».« C'était très compliqué de travailler avec Daniel,relate quelqu'un qui l'a côtoyé,même si c'est quelqu'un de brillant. Un caractère dominant, et qui prenait des risques bien trop élevés. »

L'art des paris risqués

À l'origine de sa fortune justement, un pari que personne n'aurait jamais osé faire. Quand les éoliennes poussent comme des champignons en Europe depuis le début de la décennie, laminant les revenus des centrales au gaz ou au charbon aux coûts marginaux plus élevés, EPH se propose de reprendre à prix bradés les actifs polluants et dépréciés. Daniel Kretinsky en est alors convaincu : l'Europe aura encore besoin longtemps de faire tourner ses centrales fossiles pour compléter les énergies renouvelables.« Une stratégie à contre-cycle très audacieuse », résume un acteur des fusions-acquisitions.

Au coeur des années 2010, il engrange des actifs en Italie, en Slovaquie et en Grande-Bretagne... EPH surfe aussi sur le désamour des énergéticiens pour les PECO - les pays d'Europe centrale et orientale. Alors que la fin du communisme leur avait fait miroiter des opportunités, ces pays apparaissent désormais trop petits, trop dépendants d'Etats qui ont gardé la majorité des actifs et qui sont parfois devenus ingérables comme la Hongrie.« On a vu progressivement le contexte s'obscurcir, avec des projets de loi annoncés le vendredi qui entraient en application le lundi », témoigne un ancien d'EDF.

La colère des ONG

Pas de quoi effrayer Daniel Kretinsky, qui rachète au groupe français le réseau de chaleur de Budapest.« On a eu affaire à d'excellents professionnels. J'avais rencontré des oligarques qui me paraissaient moins recommandables », poursuit cet ancien dirigeant. Concentré, choisissant ses mots avec soin quitte à reprendre une phrase qu'il jugera mal formulée, ce patron est« intelligent »,« poli »et« respecte sa parole », assurent tous ceux qui ont fait des affaires avec lui.

Dans ce terrain miné pour les affaires qu'est devenue la Hongrie, il a obtenu le feu vert de Bruxelles au début de l'année pour le rachat de Matra, une grande centrale au lignite et ses mines, en association avec Lorinc Meszaros, proche du Premier ministre souverainiste Viktor Orban... avant de revendre ses parts dans la foulée. Visiblement, les états d'âme écologistes ne l'encombrent pas quand il fait des affaires.

En 2016, la vente par le suédois Vattenfall de quatre gigantesques centrales au lignite en Allemagne et des mines attenantes a déjà déclenché la colère des ONG environnementales. Expliquant que cette opération va retarder la transition énergétique, Greenpeace, Sandbag ou Les Amis de la Terre étrillent les banques qui financent EPH et fustigent le manque de transparence de son coactionnaire PPF Investments, une société immatriculée à Jersey, sans comptes publiés.

Le goût de l'instabilité

« Il aime faire joujou avec les situations instables. Cela ne le dérange pas de prendre des risques sur des passifs parce qu'il arrivera à mettre des fusibles entre lui et les actifs. Si vous êtes Blanche-Neige, vous ne pouvez pas le faire, mais si vous êtes Daniel Kretinsky, vous pouvez. Et comme il est moins gros que les grands énergéticiens, on aura tendance à moins lui demander », analyse un Français bon connaisseur du secteur. En Pologne, l'Etat met le holà quelques mois plus tard aux velléités d'EPH de racheter à EDF sa grande centrale au charbon de Rybnik.

En mettant son veto au nom de la protection des « actifs stratégiques », Varsovie n'a-t-il eu qu'un réflexe protectionniste ou a-t-il redouté une proximité du groupe tchèque avec la Russie, dont il tente de limiter l'influence gazière ? Daniel Kretinsky s'agace d'être parfois pris pour le« bras prolongé des intérêts du Kremlin », au motif qu'EPH détient le gazoduc Eustream, qui traverse la Slovaquie et constitue l'une des principales portes d'entrée du gaz russe dans l'Union européenne.

Quand Engie et E.ON ont voulu céder leur participation de 49% dans le gazoduc et quelques autres actifs formant l'entreprise SPP, EPH s'est trouvé le seul acheteur.« Il y a quinze ans, celui qui voulait Eustream, c'était Gazprom. Mais à la fin, c'est EPH qui a acheté », se souvient un ancien acteur du dossier.

Real politik avec la Russie

« On a compris qu'ils avaient les moyens de gérer plus astucieusement les Slovaques que nous. Et ils ont une bonne relation avec les Russes », constate un autre. La relation avec Gazprom n'est pas pour autant un long fleuve tranquille. Quand le projet de gazoduc South Stream défendu par Gazprom menace ses intérêts, Daniel Kretinsky fait la tournée des partenaires du russe.« Il voulait voir si ce n'était pas plus astucieux que les Russes se bornent à faire la moitié de South Stream en laissant du transit via l'Ukraine. C'était bien sûr son intérêt mais c'était infiniment plus subtil que d'autres et avec une vision qui n'était pas manichéenne vis-à-vis des Russes », raconte l'un de ceux qu'il a rencontrés à l'époque.

Ce gazoduc est le meilleur symbole du deuxième pilier de la stratégie Kretinsky dans l'énergie : investir dans les actifs régulés aux revenus récurrents, réunis dans sa filiale EPIF. En 2015, quand EPH cherche de l'argent et annonce un projet d'introduction en Bourse que certains lisent comme un appel à candidature pour l'entrée d'un fonds, Eustream en est la pépite. L'australien Macquarie qui emporte la mise en prenant 31% d'EPIF a signé pour ces parts un chèque de« plus de 1 milliard d'euros et moins de 2 », selon une source au fait du dossier.

Une offre de dernière minute

Début 2017, l'annonce de ce mariage s'est accompagnée d'un changement de l'actionnariat chez EPH. Daniel Kretinsky est devenu seul maître à bord, avec 94% des parts, le solde allant au management. Exit son partenaire de toujours, Patrik Tkac.« C'était une condition à l'entrée de Macquarie », croit savoir cette source. Petr Kellner est, lui, sorti d'EPH il y a plusieurs années. Depuis, les anciens partenaires sont parfois rivaux, comme sur le rachat de Skoda Transportation, la plus importante entreprise de construction mécanique en Europe centrale et orientale.

« La transaction était quasiment bouclée avec Kretinsky,raconte Petr Lukac, journaliste au quotidien économiqueHospodarske Noviny.Mais Kellner a surpris tout le monde en surgissant avec une offre de dernière minute et il a remporté la mise ! »À Prague, certains évoquent des tensions entre les deux hommes depuis que Daniel Kretinsky a pris pour compagne la fille de son ancien associé, Anna Kellner, âgée d'une vingtaine d'années.

La nouvelle pépite Metro

Les affaires avec Patrik Tkac se poursuivent en dehors d'EPH : les deux hommes viennent d'investir ensemble dans Metro, le géant allemand de la vente alimentaire en gros. Un secteur dans lequel ils pourraient se montrer très ambitieux à l'avenir. Et même si dans l'énergie il voit« moins d'opportunités »maintenant que les fonds regardent les dossiers, Daniel Kretinsky n'en a peut-être pas fini : EPH regarde de près le dossier d'Uniper en France, deux centrales à charbon qui doivent fermer en 2022, deux centrales à gaz, une unité biomasse et un peu d'énergies vertes.

Avec EDF qu'il connaît bien, pourrait-il aussi investir dans les quinze réacteurs que le français exploite en Grande-Bretagne et dont il est prêt à céder 29% ?« Nous ne commentons jamais les processus en cours », répond son entourage. Les deux hommes sont aussi alliés dans Czech Media Invest (CMI) - Patrik Tkac en détient 40% -, la structure qui vient de prendre pied dansLe Monde.

L'argent d'abord, la presse ensuite

La presse, ils n'y sont pas arrivés par hasard. Ils pratiquent déjà depuis 2013 quand lui et Patrik Tkac rachètent des journaux influents en Tchéquie, parmi lesquelsBlesk, le quotidien tabloïd le plus lu du pays.

« À l'époque, plusieurs hommes d'affaires tchèques s'emparent des médias locaux, délaissés par des actionnaires étrangers (Hersant, Handelsblatt...) qui les avaient rachetés après l'effondrement du communisme », expose Michal Klima, attablé au Bella Vida Café, ambiance cossue de salon-bibliothèque, situé près du pont Charles, à Prague. Cet ex-PDG d'Economia, le groupe qui détient le quotidien économique du pays, a d'ailleurs proposé à Daniel Kretinsky de le racheter en 2008. Trop tôt, car celui-ci n'a choisi d'aller dans la presse qu'après avoir gagné beaucoup d'argent dans l'énergie.

« Quand j'ai connu une période d'accalmie qui a coïncidé avec la recomposition de la presse tchèque, j'ai convaincu mes associés d'investir dans les médias. »Hasard ou pas, son incursion dans ce secteur n'intervient que quelques mois après le rachat de médias influents par un certain Andrej Babis. Ce milliardaire très controversé aujourd'hui, qui débute alors en politique, est depuis 2014 le Premier ministre tchèque.

Une belle carte de visite

Stratégie d'influence ? Partout dans le monde, des milliardaires investissent dans les médias, de Jeff Bezos (Washington Post) et, pendant un temps, le mexicain Carlos Slim (New York Times) à Silvio Berlusconi (Mediaset), en passant par Bernard Arnault (Les Echos) ou les Dassault (Le Figaro).« Les investisseurs n'ont pas dévalué la puissance mythique des médias, relève Jean-Clément Texier, banquier d'affaires, spécialiste du secteur.On se trompe en voulant tout focaliser sur l'influence qu'ils peuvent avoir sur le produit : ce n'est pas le contenu qui les motive, c'est la position sociale qui les anoblit. »

Pour Daniel Kretinsky, le simple fait d'entrer au capital du quotidien du soir, même minoritaire, est une belle carte de visite vis-à-vis des milieux d'affaires et politiques. Essentiel pour un acteur de l'énergie... Lui définit son investissement comme un« engagement citoyen ».« Je ne veux pas influencer les médias, je veux les soutenir », pointe-t-il. Il y a cette idée chez lui que l'affaiblissement économique de la presse met en danger la démocratie, qu'il faut pour cela la sauver et que seuls des acteurs forts peuvent y parvenir. Romantique, Daniel Kretinsky ?

Le combat anti-Gafa

Un combat semble lui tenir réellement à coeur : celui de la presse face aux Gafa (Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon).« Les médias ont un combat à mener sur la régulation des Gafa. Certains concurrencent sauvagement les médias classiques, d'autres captent une part excessive de la valeur. »

En septembre, il s'est beaucoup engagé aux côtés des journaux qui ont remporté une première manche à Bruxelles pour défendre l'instauration d'un droit voisin et donc une rémunération de la part des géants du Net qui publient leurs articles gratuitement. Début octobre, il a visiblement impressionné l'influente commissaire européenne à la Concurrence Margrethe Vestager, qui l'écoutait deviser sur les Gafa lors du Globsec Tatra Summit, au bord d'un lac slovaque.« Un @DKretinsky très fort et impressionnant, plaidant pour une réglementation stable et nouvelle de la big tech », a-t-elle commenté en anglais sur Twitter.

En France comme en Tchéquie, il se présente comme le chevalier blanc. Il n'a aucune autre activité dans l'Hexagone ce qui, explique-t-il, lui évite les conflits d'intérêts. Sous-entendu : pas comme les autres détenteurs français de journaux... Il y fait allusion dans une lettre privée adressée au Pôle d'indépendance duMonde, actionnaire du journal qui représente les salariés. Il va jusqu'à accuser l'homme d'affaires tchèque Zdenek Bakala, propriétaire du journal économique local et investisseur dans l'énergie, l'agroalimentaire et la restauration, d'avoir réalisé des« opérations problématiques »dans son pays.

Une réputation non-interventionniste

Force est de reconnaître qu'en République tchèque, il a la réputation d'un patron de presse honorable. Reporters sans frontières, qui scrute l'évolution de la liberté de la presse dans le monde, ne l'épingle pas dans ses rapports, contrairement à Andrej Babis.« Il n'a pas l'air inquiétant pour les journalistes,observe Pauline Ades-Mevel, responsable de la zone Union européenne et Balkans pour RSF.Il n'est pas réputé interventionniste. »

Au Czech News Center, son groupe de presse situé entre les docks et le stade du Sparta de Prague, un bâtiment sans prétention abrite les rédactions de ses différents titres. Autrefois, le quartier n'était pas sûr, il est en train de se gentrifier. Cela tranche avec la luxueuse rue de Paris où EPH a élu domicile. C'est surtout cohérent avec ce que pèsent les activités médias dans l'empire Kretinsky : une goutte d'eau. Les 160 journalistes des tabloïds quotidiensBlesketAha !y sont regroupés dans l'immense salle de cette ancienne brasserie. Tous côte à côte, sur plusieurs grandes lignes de tables sans espace entre elles.

« L'investissement de Daniel Kretinsky dans les journaux en France a surpris jusqu'à Prague, sourit Michal Pur, qui pilote le site Info.cz sur l'actualité hors Prague, lancé il y a deux ans.On a hâte de développer des synergies, d'échanger des savoir-faire. »Des équipes deMariannesont déjà venues sur place.

Passager clandestin

Bientôt le tour duMonde? L'homme d'affaires a encore tout à prouver aux journalistes et à Xavier Niel, qu'il ne connaît pas, s'il entend gagner le contrôle partagé du titre. Même s'il s'en cache, c'est clairement son intention puisqu'il a déjà fait une première tentative cet été. Pour l'heure, Matthieu Pigasse, Xavier Niel et le Pôle d'indépendance négocient un « droit d'agrément » afin qu'à l'avenir, tout changement de contrôle puisse être soumis à leur accord préalable.

Un droit dont Daniel Kretinsky a questionné la légitimité dans une interview auxEchos... Malgré tous les chèques imaginables, les salariés ont le pouvoir de bloquer son accession au trône. Un long travail de séduction lui sera donc nécessaire pour faire disparaître l'image de « passager clandestin » qui lui colle à la peau ces dernières semaines.

Du magazine politique à la presse people

La panoplie des journaux de Daniel Kretinsky va du tabloïd (Blesk) au magazine politique, social et culturel (Reflex) en passant par le quotidien sportif (Sport) et people (Aha !). Photos criardes, titres racoleurs, promotions pour les poivrons Lidl en une, playmate sur l'avant-dernière page :Bleskn'est pas le titre le plus glorieux du groupe. C'est pourtant le plus lu du pays ! Si son groupe de presse est numéro 1 national, il accuse du retard sur internet. Il y a deux ans, il a recruté Michal Pur, pour piloter le lancement d'Info.cz, un pure player sur l'actualité internationale. Rien à voir, bien sûr, avec le fait que Daniel Kretinsky réalise 90% de ses affaires hors de Tchéquie... Récemment, il a déclaré dansLes Echosvouloir publier des articles duMondesur Info.cz. La direction du quotidien du soir n'était pas au courant. L'un de ses conseillers aurait aussi évoqué l'hypothèse explosive d'un rapprochement entreTéléramaetTélé 7 Jours. Le mariage de la carpe et du lapin... Certains s'interrogent sur le pourquoi du rachat au prix fort des titres de Lagardère,Elle,France Dimancheou encoreTélé 7 Jours. Un ticket pour l'avenir, le jour où Arnaud Lagardère voudrait vendre Europe 1,Paris Matchet leJDD? Avec ces trois médias d'influence, il changerait indéniablement de dimension dans l'Hexagone.

Le foot, un échec financier

Daniel Kretinsky est surtout connu à Prague pour être propriétaire du club de foot Sparta. Il y a investi plus de 1 milliard de couronnes et perdu beaucoup d'argent. Problèmes de management, mauvais choix de transferts... Le foot est un échec financier pour l'homme d'affaires que l'on a récemment entendu pester,« la frustration prend le dessus », après la deuxième élimination successive du Sparta des phases qualificatives de la Ligue Europa. Selon l'édition tchèque deForbes, il devrait d'ailleurs annoncer une « perte record » pour la saison 2017-18 à quelque 700 millions de couronnes. Pas question de racheter d'autres clubs à ce stade. Il y a quelques jours, l'hypothèse de son intérêt pour l'AS Roma et l'AC Milan s'est répandue comme une traînée de poudre dans la presse italienne, avant qu'il ne la démente. À vrai dire, il n'est pas fan de foot... Lui, c'est plutôt le basket qu'il pratique.

urn:contentItem:5VC5-XSK1-DYWJ-F2JC-00000-00Daniel Meere: What lessons can financial advisers take from open banking?2019-02-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:39ZLexisNexisDaniel Meere: What lessons can financial advisers take from open banking?julian.marr@incisivemedia.com(Julian Marr)

Open banking took effect in January 2018 to shake up the way in which customers - both individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) - interact with their banks. It set out to pave the way for new products and services from those offering mobile and digital banking to help consumers manage their money more effectively and secure better deals for financial services.

Acting as a boon for the growing cohort of mobile-only banks, it has also been a wake-up call for more traditional players - prompting them fundamentally to reassess the way they treat their customers. In some respects, its introduction is the Retail Distribution Review (RDR) moment for the banking sector, which put the investor at the centre of the advice process to ensure transparency and fairness.

Of course, the introduction of the RDR led to the rise of a new class of investor - the so-called 'advice orphans', whose portfolios are too small to be profitable for advisers to service via traditional wealth management. Cue the entrance of robo-advisers such as Nutmeg and Wealthify to fill the void and the rise of passive investments, such as ETFs, relying on algorithms and automation to inform asset allocation.

With every new item of regulation comes industry disruption, seemingly creating an industry polarised by those clinging on to traditional business models and new market entrants offering a revolutionary way of approaching finance.

In banking, the familiar high street faces have historically relied on inertia to retain customers but this is no longer the case - open APIs (application program interfaces) enable these customers to share their financial information with other providers, switch to other banks much more easily and conduct transactions through banks and non-banks alike.

Monzo, the app-only challenger bank, has already attracted more than one million customers over its short history - a clear indication not only to banks but to all those offering financial services, the advisory community included, that they ignore innovation at their peril. Whether or not financial advisers may be resistant to embrace change, their clients increasingly are not.

Digital access and servicing are now part of banking life for many. Personal financial management tools and round-up savings services are more mainstream, which in turn have prompted customers to take greater control of their finances.

Marketplace banking and comparison sites also arm customers with sufficient information to make important financial decisions without the need for a human adviser. This collective set of nudges could be the tipping point for adviser interest in a more digital relationship with clients.

The perception among many financial advisers is that adopting digital change is either not relevant for their business models or is prohibitively expensive to implement - indeed, the thought of where to start might seem overwhelming.

What leads therefore can the adviser community take from the banking sector to help them along their digital journey? The experience among banks offers the advice industry a broad playbook covering product design and positioning, channel, service models and the construction of financial ecosystems or marketplaces.

First, product positioning. Within banking, services for SMEs in particular have often been criticised for being far too homogenous, not reflecting the needs of a highly diverse sector. Expect to see far more innovation in this area as the 'alterative remedies package' rolls out, distributing some £750m carved from RBS in recompense for its 2008 bail-out, to encourage greater competition in SME banking.

This should lead to much greater differentiation of offering to meet the needs of distinct business-types, putting the customer, not products, at the heart of the proposition. Similarly, advisers can evolve their businesses to create specific, highly-targeted offerings rather than a one-size fits all advice model.

Millennial investing, sharia investing, investing for women, investing at point of retirement - these all provide opportunities to tailor advice to differing client types. In the US, for example, Ellevest has built a business focused on the distinct investment needs of women.

Advisers can help retain clients or target new market niches by referencing what experience different groups demand rather than focusing on the vehicle that takes them along their financial journey.

And niches need not be exclusive. Sharia banking now attracts more non-Muslim than Muslim clients due to a combination of better returns and an approach to finance based on ethical considerations that increasingly have a strong resonance with a much wider spectrum of society. This mirrors the huge growth of interest in ESG investing in the wealth management sector.

How advisers service their clients can also be enhanced through technology. Banking customers have grown comfortable communicating with AI-driven chatbots to deal with complex requests.

By introducing this type of service model, advisory firms can free up time to concentrate on higher-value activities - from face-to-face annual reviews to ensuring compliance with shifting regulatory requirements. The greater efficiencies this creates can have a positive impact on a business´s bottom line, which should be welcomed in an environment of profit margin compression.

Chatbots, while introducing efficiency, may seem to dehumanise client interaction. Other communication channels can, however, be opened through technology to foster far closer client relationships. Banking customers increasingly rely on apps to engage with their providers, giving them budgeting advice, prompting them on overdraft limits and alerting them to new products or offers.

Financial advisers can similarly open a much more constant dialogue with their clients to provide real-time notifications on market movements and investment opportunities, reminders of tax deadlines and other helpful context-based nudges. These combine to nurture much closer engagement and foster a stronger connection between client and adviser.

Talk of creating a financial ecosystem or marketplace is increasingly common in the banking sector, led by online-only challengers. Legacy banks might be wary of introducing their customers to other financial service providers, preferring to cross-sell their own products and keeping business in the family, but digital newcomers have recognised they can engender client loyalty through a more altruistic approach.

Starling, for example, is focused on pure banking services but has built a platform through which its customers can access a wide range of related services, from accounting software to managing receipts to travel insurance.

Advisers can similarly benefit from a marketplace approach - for example, platforms providing access to robo-advice via an adviser´s own marketplace can extend the range of services available to clients without having to invest in developing the service themselves.

This enables them to retain the core client relationship, while adding specific products or services that would otherwise be provided directly by others. This should be a consideration for advisers at the smaller end of the spectrum who want to concentrate on their strengths in financial planning but are keen to embed themselves more deeply in clients' financial psyche.

The perceived expense of digital transformation or a lack of technological ability may be considered a barrier to entry for many smaller advisory firms but this need not be the case. In implementing a digital strategy, it is important to start small rather than contemplating a wholescale technological overhaul. The success stories in digital banking highlight the importance of focusing on features that delight customers over the completeness of a digital offering.

To return to Monzo, which is in effect a very simple banking app, the ability to freeze a lost card until it has been recovered is highly prized by customers. This combination of imagination and an understanding of their needs has impressed their clients far more than big tech investment.

Open banking has emphasised much greater collaboration between traditional market players and innovative fintechs. This is evidenced by the Capabilities and Innovation Fund, which encourages greater fintech participation in SME banking and the UK is arguably the most fertile environment for the sector in Europe.

This is something advisers should seek to exploit. Having identified which part of the overall customer experience they wish to own, financial advisers can capitalise on wider investment in fintech by partnering with businesses leading the technological revolution to complement the services they offer their clients.

This effectively outsources both the expense and risk of developing new technologies in-house to those with the expertise to do so. The potential offered by collaboration with fintechs is applicable equally to an adviser's front and back-office infrastructure. It can open new ways of interacting with clients and providing advice and services as well as streamlining administrative functions and reporting.

Just as in banking, where there are still many customers who prefer to visit a branch to conducting business online, so with financial advice there will continue to be clients who favour a face-to-face relationship with their adviser.

This need not change. Instead, by following the lead of banks in offering innovative and more efficient ways of working with customers, advisers can embrace the evolution of their industry.

A more digital approach can enhance a client's overall experience by streamlining specific areas of a service. This frees up an adviser to concentrate on those who have a much higher added-value impact to the relationship, essential in both retaining and growing a client base.

Daniel Meere is UK managing director of international management consulting firm Axis Corporate

urn:contentItem:5PFG-FP51-DXH2-64D8-00000-00Danone SA at Barclays Global Consumer Staples Conference - Final2017-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:40ZLexisNexis090617a10911348.748Danone SAat Barclays Global Consumer Staples Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Emmanuel Faber

Danone - CEO, Vice Chairman & Non-Independent Director

Conference Call Participants

* Alexander Piers Smith

Barclays PLC, Research Division - Research Analyst

Presentation

ALEXANDER PIERS SMITH, RESEARCH ANALYST, BARCLAYS PLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Okay. Good morning, everybody. I think it's probably time we should get going for our first presentation this morning. For those of you at the back, hope you're all well rested. I'm Alex Smith, and I cover European food and HBC for Barclays. So first up this morning, we have Danone. And it's my absolute pleasure to welcome up on stage, Emmanuel Faber, CEO; and CÃ©cile Cabanis, CFO. And I'd also like to thank Danone for providing all the delicious snacks which you might have had the chance to indulge in from across the room.

So most of us know Danone has transformed itself over the years into one of the most health focused and consumer on trend staples companies in our universe. And of course, culminating with the WhiteWave acquisition from earlier this year. I think in that context it's not too uncontroversial to say that the company's currently underperforming its significant growth potential. Growth is set to improve in the second half of this year and the company has a plan to take growth up to its target of 4% to 5% by 2020 and I'm sure we'll hear more from the team about that in due course. The group also has amongst the most ambitious cost-saving plans across the space, and a target to take the operating margin up by 300 basis points to (inaudible) by 2020. These are just a couple of the hot topics around Danone, which is a pretty busy equity story today. And with that backdrop I should probably stop talking now and hand it over to Emmanuel. Thank you very much, Emmanuel.

EMMANUEL FABER, CEO, VICE CHAIRMAN & NON-INDEPENDENT DIRECTOR, DANONE: Thank you, Alex. Good morning, everyone, 7:30, back-to-school. Thank you for the opportunity once again, we never miss this opportunity of back-to-school to offer us the opportunity to share our passion about what we create with Danone with your support finally to your benefit. It's as Alex said, a very rich story, which is driven by the vision that you have here with our new signature One Planet One Health. We believe this is a guiding point for every consumer in the world for the next possible future, and we want this to be our own guiding point in creating value today and tomorrow. Exactly 3 years ago we embarked, if I can get the charts, maybe this one would work better. Okay, let me try something else. I'm ready. Thank you.

I hope that's me doing this. Yes, apparently it is. We embarked, in exactly 3 years ago, in a very deep transformation for Danone. A transformation that is aimed at bringing an agenda of profitable growth, restoring that agenda. And bringing it in a vision that is truly addressing the needs of tomorrow and therefore, preparing the company for tomorrow. We've run that agenda for 3 years. And earlier this year, we decided that we needed to double down, to accelerate, adjust what is now a 3-year program to go to 2020 and I'd like to walk you through this transformation.

First of all, the first couple of years, 2014-2016, we delivered on a rebalanced agenda of profitability and growth. Starting with growth, with an average 4% like-for-like growth for the company on these 3 years. A sustained improvement in our recurring operating margin. Actually the 120 bps cumulative improvement is the highest ever that we had on a 3-year span and that will continue. And that led to what, for Danone, as you know is quite new. But I can tell you now extremely strong focus agenda on EPS growth. 8.8% average EPS growth, consistent EPS growth, during that period of time.

Then the future. The future because we saw, as we shared with you, number of opportunities to go faster. Number of challenges that we could resolve quicker if we were to decouple for the first time, not creating only one historical engine for Danone, which was growth. But using another one to fly, 2 engines to fly: growth and efficiency in a decoupled manner with one line of direction, consistent EPS growth through 2017 to 2020. Let me start by where we want to go. Where we want to go is very clear. Sales of 4% to 5% growth by 2020 on a like-for-like basis. Recurring operating margin beyond 16%, which combined together will create a consistent EPS growth over the period of time. And on capital allocation, a clear discipline with a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio below 3x by 2020. And capturing the ROIC opportunity, the roadmap that we have back to about 12% by 2020. This way, we believe, we will prepare for what Danone remains uniquely a strong, profitable, sustainable growth potential as a company.

We actually started to deliver on that journey. If you look at our first half, there's been a widely discussed already slow start to the year. And despite that slow start to the year in terms of growth, we've actually posted the highest ever period-to-period improvement of our recurring operating margin, 91 basis points. No surprise that it delivered significant EPS growth, strong EPS growth of 11%, poising us well into our ability to deliver double-digit EPS growth for the full year of 2017. And in addition, about capital allocation and what we do with our cash, 24% free cash flow growth, which bodes well to the agenda of deleveraging that we have for the company.

Let me now start about the future. First of all, first of the 2 big engines. The 300 bps improvement target that we have for the next 3 years, driven of course by growth, but beyond this by an accelerated efficiency program. 300 bps based on enablers that are already in place. A Protein program, our own ZBB approach, which is going to save us EUR 1 billion on indirect purchasing. A big change in the way they're working. We intend to let EUR 300 million of this flow into the operating margin by 2020. And that number starts with next year, EUR 100 million additional operating profit led by the Protein program.

The second big driver of efficiency and margin improvement is our $300 million by 2020 WhiteWave synergies. As you know, $225 million of that are cost synergies, the $75 million of the rest is EBIT from revenue synergy. So very much skewed in our numbers, in our plan today on cost efficiency in the WhiteWave merger. Third, structural efficiencies, and I'll come back to that. We've continued to work on our organizations, on the way we purchase, on the way we manufacture, we transport and this is a multi-annual program that will continue to deliver productivities over time. A very disciplined approach in resource allocation. We actually discussed that exactly a year ago in this place about how we refused to fuel some tactical growth that we believed wouldn't create long-term sustainable growth through the period. And finally, our continued commitment on our legacy dairy business beyond WhiteWave to improve the margin in the next 3 years by an additional 200 bps from what it was in 2014 at constant exchange rates.

So these are the main drivers of our efficiency programs. I'm very confident in our ability to deliver because the key enablers are already in place. One big chunk of the transformation of the organization for Danone has been 2.5 years ago when we decided to go for a One Danone organization in 30 different clusters of geographies. As you know, this is now fully in place. This is the backbone of the local Danone organizations that allow us to mutualize cross categories, the organizations of these countries to run cross categories, a number of both top-line and cost initiatives, and to bring the right level of expertise to make sure we continue to drive our business in those clusters.

Second, Beyond Budget process that's been running for 18 months now, led by CÃ©cile, which allows us to quarterly reallocate resources on a very flexible manner and to make sure we put our money on profitable growth opportunities only and make sure we also resource our cost efficiency programs.

Third, procurement. DanTrade is a program that exists for 5 years at Danone, which we have not yet fully implemented both in terms of divisions and in terms of geographies. It's mostly covers today Europe and dairy. It's poised to cover the whole of the world. In a couple of weeks' time, maximum, I will have the pleasure to announce the creation and the recruitment of a very high caliber Chief Procurement Officer that will have, as a purpose, to make sure that this happens deep, fast and efficient in the organization. Thirdly, on the new regional footprints, you may remember 9 months ago, we decided that we would delegate from the executive committee of Danone, which I shrank to a limited number of people to accelerate the rate at which we are making decision, the efficiency of this limited team, we actually delegated to a team of 15 regional leaders company-wide decisions that they make at their level committing the whole company and this is to make sure that we're making decisions much faster closer to the markets because they direct with the 30 clusters that I just mentioned before every day. And so we believe they are at the right place to make those decisions for the future of Danone, whether this is on efficiency or whether this is on top line topics. So the enablers are already in place today from an organizational standpoint for us to deliver -- continue to deliver on our efficiency journey.

H1 2017 is actually on these programs on track starting with Protein, our ZBB program. We have started 3 pilots already live: Mexico; France, including our headquarters in Paris; and Germany. We will have the learnings of these by the end of the year. Already the Q4 is getting to see implementation of further geographies. And as I said, we expect EUR 100 million of savings into our margin next year from these programs.

The second is the adaptation of our European Dairy organization. I chose to share it with you again because I think this is an important example on how we're addressing those. Because the reality is that the market is evolving fast, you learn, you have to learn fast both from your failures and from your successes. In that case, when it comes to the Activia relaunch, that was much spoken about a year ago, we alerted you already back in December last year that it didn't reach the expected results. By the 15th of January, we'd made a decision to change the organization in Europe. By the 14th of Feb, during our full year release, I shared with you that we had change all the leadership team in Dairy Europe to make sure we readdressed properly the opportunities there.

4 months later, we had changed the organization itself, shrank it from 9 to 5 clusters. Making sure that we divided by 2 the number of processes and decision making in the top management of Dairy in Europe to speed up the decision making both in top line and on efficiency. And by the Q2, we had changed and populated with new leaders, all of the 5 clusters plus the leading person in Dairy in Europe. This was made in a swift manner. And I'd like to just add one thing. We did that because I'm -- we are strong believers that the fit of the people that we put on the mission with that task in a very fast evolving manner is the root of the success. But when we're wrong, we need to know fast, we need to decide and change fast, which is what we did, what we will continue to do. And by the way, I have to say that beyond making sure we pick the right people, are poised for success, we also have to continue to look at organizations as a very adaptive factor to success. So you have seen and you will continue to see our organization evolve as I think we are in a very fast changing environment and we need to continue to do this.

The third aspect is the WhiteWave synergy agenda. We finally closed WhiteWave in April, as you know. So we had about 2 months of running the company in the first half of the year. We used that 2 months to do very quick symbolic but important topics including grounding aviation, closing the Denver office, starting the synergies and the cost in organization synergies, making sure we had 1 sales force. In only a matter of a few weeks, we were able to create a slate of unparalleled salesforce organization in the refrigerated aisle here in the U.S. with great leaders from both sides making sure that all our customers here had their dedicated new key accounts. Most of the time they knew them before from either of the organizations. And that was one of the great successes of the first 2 months of the integration of WhiteWave in the first half of the year.

With, on top of that, the first few synergies, essentially cost synergies that started to flow in already in 2 months. And finally, I was talking about the structural work that we're doing on our efficiencies. I'm particularly satisfied in the context, which I think a number of you remembered us probably telling you already 2 years ago that we felt 2017 was going to be a challenging year from a raw material standpoint because after the big decline in the price of milk for a couple of years, we expected 2017 to go back in terms of input prices. This is what happened. And you can see that 400 bps of inflation in overall raw materials for Danone on the first half of the year. And yet 90% of it compensated by efficiency gains and the way we've managed our mix on the marketplace.

The next big engine to fly to the direction of 2020 is growth, obviously. And why is this, and how is this company uniquely positioned to sequentially accelerate our growth? Let me come back again to where we want to be by 2020. We shared these numbers with all of you who attended our investor seminar back in May. By 2020, our sales growth, organic, will be 4% to 5% with basically 3 of our macro categories beyond 5%. And one, the international essential dairy and plant-based business so outside of North America, between 3% and 4%. You heard me say and I can repeat, I'm extremely confident in our ability to reach these numbers. A few reasons why. I've said it, and I repeat it, we are constantly self-disrupting this organization to fit all growth opportunities that we see.

For those of you were at Evian and Evian with us for the seminar, we spent some time about discussing one of the critical topic I have as a manager in such a transformation, which is the pace of change. We are constantly measuring, taking the pulse of our organization to make sure that people keep up with the pace of change. That we are going as fast as we need to but in the same time as fast as they can go as well. And this is also why, from time to time we've been changing roles, people, organization to make sure that we mitigate and we optimize our ability to culturally change, to collectively change the pace at which this company moves, the direction in which it moves. In particular, and I'll come back to that, the collective efficiency agenda that we've created which is totally new for a company like Danone.

The second reason I think we're geared for a strong growth and by 2020 of 4% to 5% growth number on a like-for-like basis is from the comeback of emerging countries. You probably remember Latin America 15 years ago, you probably remember Russia not so far ago when we acquired Unimilk, merged it with Danone in Russia. And we started with a margin at 0 basically, given the ban on the number of foodstuff at that point in time by the government. Given the fires that had destroyed harvests and fields and the price of milk had skyrocketed 40% just before the closing. Anyway, we started with 0, we're now double-digit margin in Russia a few years later. We are growing in Russia as you know in CIS overall, low to mid-single digits in a difficult environment. So Russia had its highs and lows. We're managing this and that continues to deliver.

You know that China, we've been mentioning for now a number of quarters, the transition in China, of course, the Early Life Nutrition transition. But also the beverage transition into the new normal of China, which is now gradually fading away. As you know, we are at the end of that transition and that is good news for our Water business in total. So China's gone through its truth and it's going to grow again. Mentioning Early Life Nutrition, we've reached a record market share for our brands in China. Continue to be #1 in Early Life Nutrition. It's an incredible job that's been done by the teams locally. We've been talking with you about Brazil, probably a big point of disappointment for us for a few quarters already and this is not finished. But all in all, through this transition we continue to believe that there is a huge traction for our categories, for our brands in emerging countries going through a transition now and they'll be back.

And lastly it's because we are executing on efficiencies. And these efficiencies through our resource allocation process are already allowing us, and increasingly so in the future including with the put in program, to reinvest behind the right categories and the right brands. And talking about these like categories and brands, Danone has an unparalleled growth biased portfolio of categories. You can look at the past, horizontal; at the future, vertical. In dark gray, this is other food categories. In light gray -- sorry, other beverage categories. In light gray, it is other food category. In blue, this is our categories. You can look at in the way you want. They as categories globally were growing anywhere between 3% and 11%. In the past, they're poised to grow anywhere between 4% to 9% in the future. These are our categories.

On these categories, we believe we have incredibly strong brands and positions. Early Life Nutrition, #2 worldwide but the fastest-growing of all competitors in the marketplace with a great slate of brands. Which growth is going to be driven by secular consumer trends, which I have highlighted here. An increasing number of affluent middle-class and that is true anywhere in emerging countries short to midterm. And the resuming of growth of the market of Early Life Nutrition in China is a very, very good news for us. The 1,000 days awareness in which Danone is a global leader, how nutrition changes lives during the first 1,000 days. Favorite nutrition needs, allergies prevalence are growing everywhere. Very important because we are 1 of the 2 largest, most expert companies in the world to deliver appropriate solutions for babies and toddlers in that space. And journey management, which our own digital journey is helping us to improve, which is the way we carry our relationship with a pregnant mother through toddlership and even longer. When we see, for instance, that in the U.S. the point of disruption of a family diet going to organic, for instance, it is where baby is actually coming into the family. So if you enter at that point in time, you can create a lifelong relationship that changes the way people eat and drink and changes the way you interact with your brands with these people. So journey management is of course, a very important topic and that includes nutritionists, that includes health care practitioners, that includes the prescription that doctors are making for the solutions that we're bringing to the kid situations.

Advanced Medical Nutritions, which is our second export nutrition category. As you know, it's a smaller but fast-growing very profitable category; #1 in Europe but fastly growing in Latin America, in Russia, in China where we're #1 as well. This is a business that is poised for growth given our positions and given the underlying social health economics, I would say; aging population all over the world; and sometimes faster than we all anticipated is bringing special needs for people metabolisms beyond a certain point in age. The prevalence of chronic diseases and metabolism diseases, we're providing some absolutely vital solutions of nutrition for babies to the end of life. Some people are only eating our products and therefore, the ability for our teams to create recipes, to create solutions that embark all of the complexity of the metabolism through heavy science but in the same time a huge work from a food and alimentation standpoint creating the texture, the [organ electives], the consumer experience, the recipes.

The social experience that they get from using our products is critical because this is an element of compliance. And doctors who now have a clear understanding even on government level, how much nutrition is actually saving public money because it keeps people out of hospital basically for many reasons. It's the compliance with the prescription is critical. And when you have to take the same bottle of the same product in morning, midday and at night for your lifetime, you can imagine that the variety of the way you intake that food is critical to the way you actually make sure you get the right level of nutrient in the right way. So this is one of the very interesting patterns where expert nutrition really meets the cultural, the social aspects of what alimentation all means to all of us.

The importance of outpatient care is growing. So we've been developing also direct contact and digital, physical contacts and journey management out of hospitals and clinics for patients including in care homes. So we have services that we provide around nutrition that's broader than purely the product itself. And that brings us into a digital space, which is very interesting in terms of complementary services. And all the data that we can share and not only with our patients but also with the healthcare sector that we support through this division.

The third one is our Water business. We're #3 in volumes. We're also the fastest-growing global water business. It's an incredibly powerful slate of brands that we have, international and local. They're very -- they've been very innovative, innovation has been absolutely critical to revive the growth of this category. Sustainability has been fundamental to address the -- all the concerns but also the opportunities behind the Water category. Sustainability is critical, that's part of the DNA of our brands and that's really one of the points on which they are making a difference. And we believe there is growth as much as Euro Monitor and others are projecting for the future based on the various consumer drivers that you see here, including the fact that there is clearly a switch from sugary drinks to much healthier hydration solutions by consumers all over the place.

Whether they do that by themselves, whether they do that because there are taxes on sugary drinks or whether this is a combination of both because the offering is changing through government boost, through education boards in universities and schools or through even customers. We are seeing more traction in these than in the volumes of big soft drinks. So that will continue to grow and that's been a very successful business for us.

Fresh Dairy, #1 globally, of course. The unparalleled slate of brands that we have is also poised for growth. We are very clear on this. This is not a commoditized category. We've - we are seeing a lot of innovations. All the innovations are high-priced sophisticated innovations. So the problems that we see in this category is not related to the category, it's relating to our own execution and that's back to a couple of comments I made before. Why we believe where we'll grow is because there has been never such a conversation about gut microbiotas and the global metabolism of humans.

Here in the U.S., there is a new trend that I'm sure you've seen about probiotics. Probiotics started in 1919 for Danone. We have 3,000 of them research in our probiotics library that we can use to engineer new solutions against them. It's an unparalleled richness that we have. And it's clearly driven by the naturality, the simpleness of what dairy is overall. And dairy continues to grow in most of emerging countries. It will continue to grow and we are uniquely placed to catch up where we should be and where we are not yet and that's part, as you know, of our gradual re-acceleration plan.

The great addition of our plant-based and food and beverages -- food and WhiteWave acquisition, incredible slate of brands and businesses here with a #1 position in the U.S, #1 in Europe, as you know, 7x bigger in Europe but -- than the #2. White space is all over the place to continue to grow in plant-based and dairy alternative solutions across the world as more and more people are becoming flexitarian. They're not vegans, but they're flexitarian. It's become mainstream here in this country, which is really what triggered our interest into the WhiteWave acquisition.

WhiteWave team's been tremendously successful in bringing this as a mainstream solution now. Which requires, by the way, now that it's mainstream with 30% household penetration a different set in terms of how we innovate and continue to grow, which is also creating traction is the way we are organizing WhiteWave and DanonWave as the combined entity here in North America, to continue to the incredible potential growth of this plant-based categories. Lots of innovation whitespace too. I think there is an untapped opportunity to do something that our WhiteWave friends didn't have time to do probably or the opportunity, which is Alpro's been growing on their agenda with an innovation research development integrated ability, which is truly unparalleled in the world. That's a jewel for us as a company. And I think that can also continue to inspire the next wave of growth for the coming future of our brands here in the U.S. to restore the growth including of the great Silk brand. The good news being, that the category has restarted growing as we speak right now for plant-based in the U.S.

Finally, coffee creamers and beverages, a new, exciting category for us here in this country, potentially beyond. We're #2, as you know, to a significantly bigger one. But by far the fastest growing slate of brands. Hugely innovative, very successful innovations driven by the WhiteWave team here. Multi-brands, multi-formats, multi-nutritional solutions with the slate of growing from organic milk to plant-based and a number of different plant-based solutions. We see a lot of growth potential because of coffee popularity and the continued growth of the coffee consumption all over the world basically and here in the U.S. as well. We're offering better for you than traditional creaming solutions with a number of these solutions. And we see more and more creaming as the coffee consumption grows, because in particular, in this country where coffee is not exactly what we European people would call it, we see more and more consumers as they grow their consumption, willing to enrich, I would say, the flavor and the experiment with a variety you of creaming solutions. So great potential there as well.

In a nutshell, these categories, the positions that we have make Danone uniquely fit in a fast-changing consumer landscape. First of all, 100% healthy categories now in our portfolio. It's been 10 years of hard work to come to this portfolio; we're there now. Second, we see a lot of local traction. You heard me speak about local. I think this alimentation, this food revolution that we're seeing all over the world will mean, is already meaning that people want to understand locally what their food is, where it's coming. They feel that local is safer, that local is more sustainable, that local is closer but basically local means they reach their own sovereignty and food. And so the fact that more than half of our portfolio has been historically built as local brands. For us, compared to some meager brands that we see operating in the space is a big advantage that on which we are doubling down in terms of building strategically the agenda for these local brands.

And the third one is that we're not afraid of making bold moves. We're not about marginal changes. Everything we do since 3 years are radical, deep transformations. And when a year ago, we decided to go all non-GMO here, saying that by the end of this year, in 4 months' time, we will label GMOs in our product, whatever the regulation was. And when we decided to transition half of our slate of the brands here into non-GMOs, that's a very consumer friendly move that I think is just an example of what many brands should be doing if they want to be part of the future. Seven, before I conclude reasons why to summarize why I believe Danone is uniquely positioned in this consumer landscape.

We have a passion for what we do. And at Danone, everything starts with people. The level of engagement in our people, as you know, those of you who are at the investor seminar, the sustainable engagement, the passion that people have, as we measure it by going direct to 90,000 of them. Asking them directly the questions and looking at the answers is unparalleled. We are close to some very fancy big tech companies in terms of engaging the people. Way beyond our competition. I think that makes a huge difference in the pace at which we can change this organization.

Second, I said it. Leading brands, 100% healthy categories, a well-balanced geographical footprint. Third, we are self-disrupting ourselves. And I want to continue to build, and I said that an adaptive organization because I truly believe that we need to continue to move as fast as we see the opportunities around us. There is, I can assure you, a full new but full commitment to collective efficiency, which did not exist 3 years ago and we're creating the conditions for that every day. There is a pioneer, a very innovative, I would say, probably unparalleled in many ways, platform of socially-driven business rooted sustainability initiatives, which I think are going to be very important for the future of our brands.

The sixth is we have a very people-centric culture that allows us to engage in a truly different manner with companies, with NGOs, governments, with our people, recruiting people from smaller companies that join us very interestingly to re-nurture the culture and the DNA of Danone. And finally, I think it's very important, we are managing time horizons. We are not focusing on any of the 3 short, mid and long. We are just making sure we manage each and every of them. Just one is not enough. One is just not enough. And I think this is what makes the whole thing hold together because this is what actually brings the meaning of what we do every day.

So I'll just finish by saying that we have this arrow, you know it. That's our past 2, 1 day strong, profitable, sustainable growth. We continue to believe that company has the right way to aspire to be there. By 2020, we'll not be exactly there because growth will still be below 5%, so 4% to 5% in terms of growth. And working back from now to 2020, we will continue to build a profitable, sustainable growth agenda starting with this year, delivering consistent EPS growth.

Thank you for being with us. Thank you for your interest. I really believe we're creating a unique company with your support.

ALEXANDER PIERS SMITH: I would like to thank very much Emmanuel for his engaging presentation and for being with us here today.
